paper.title: Sorting out zero-knowledge
paper.venue: Theory and Application of Cryptographic Techniques
paper.abstract: In their 1985 paper, Goldwasser, Micali and Rackoff set forth the notion of zero-knowledge interactive proofs [GMR1]. This seminal paper generated considerable activity around the world. In the span of a few years, a substantial number of results were obtained by different groups of researchers. Among those, the following two theorems make an intriguing pair: :[55],"[F], together with Boppana, Hastad and Zachos [BHZ]: The existence of a perfect zero-knowledge protocol for an NP-complete problem would imply that the polynomial hierarchy :[81],"Chaum and Crepeau [BCC]: There exists a perfect zero-knowledge protocol for the polynomial hierarchy :[93],"has not collapsed! Of course, the resolution of this apparent paradox is that the above two results strongly depend on fundamentally incompatible definitions of what a protocol is.
